reviewText:
It's impressive for a game made in RPGmaker, but the more you play it, the more its flaws start to stand out.

First, let's start with the good. It's fun to roam around the city, especially at low levels and alone when every encounter can be potentially life-ending. Combat is unforgiving when you don't have a gun or the ammo to use it, meaning that you need to be judicious where and when you fight. It also has a nice post-apocalyptic vibe to it.

So that's what's good. Past a certain point, the open exploration with little guidance starts to become frustrating. One of the selling points of this game was that you can establish your own colony, which is nice and thematic. However, I've spent eight hours on the game, crawled over the map, and found nothing. None of the characters have ever mentioned it to me either, so I guess I could keep playing if I just wanted to crawl the map endlessly looking for it.

Speaking of which, the map they provide in the game is fairly useless. Unless you're standing at the margins of the map, it's hard to get a real sense for where you are until you've effectively memorized the relations of where everything is anyway. I know that might be realistic, but in a game where things are abstractly rendered at best, it makes finding your way around really difficult. Why not a coordinate system?

Quest marking, or even writing it down in the journal you have would be a tremendous help too. There's something infuriating in finishing a quest and then not remembering where the quest giver was, leading you to wander the map just to find them.

Scavenging is also too effective. My strategy of looting every container and reselling what I didn't need (revolutionary, I know) left me with so many tabs that I could effectively buy everything my main character needed and have plenty left over. My safe was stocked to the gills with everything I could ever need, although the fact that it doesn't sort goods at all for you means that finding anything was incredibly difficult.

Maybe if I was anal retentive I would need to buy everything for my NPCs, but only one of them can fight with you at a time, and some are far, far better than others. (Was Nadia supposed to be useful? I got her up to level 5 and she never did more than a point of damage). Once you get a gun and enough ammo, which is easy because money is no issue, just make you sure you have an NPC who can use one, and fights will never be a real challenge again.

The story is nothing to write home about. A man kidnaps your family, you go after him, revenge, blah blah blah. Not bad, but nothing special, and its non-linearity makes it easy to forget it ever happened.

This game was fun for a while, but I happened to buy it when I desperately needed short distractions. Under normal circumstances, I wouldn't spend $10 on this, so unfortunately I can't recommend this.

Updated review as final release came out.  Waste Walkers is a Dystopian RPG game where you play a survivor trying to survive in the ruins.  Along the way, you'll encounter mutants, bandits, and feral animals roaming the cityscape.  You'll find your fair share of allies if you prove yourself useful and plenty of unique places to explore.

Waste Walkers uses the RPG Maker engine, though heavily modified by scripts.  I have no problem with this, but some people are very opinionated on it, so I'm mentioning it here so you won't be 'surprised.'

Things you'll find in this game:Visible enemy encounters. There are also some 'random' encounters, but these are rare enough that they aren't intrusive and serve very well at keeping you from becoming complacent.
A large variety of combat weapons to suit style, each with their own individual stats affecting Accuracy, Speed, and ability to inflict nasty things like Bleeding, Stunning, and loss of teeth.
A Level up System allowing customization of Stats encompassing Strength, Dexterity, Endurance, and Constitution.
A skill system utilizing Passive Skills and Techniques for combat.  In addition, there are Weapon Specific techniques depending on the death-dealer you have equipped.  Got a Longbow, you can make a Pinning Shot to lower an enemy's Dex and Speed.  Got an Assault Rifle, fire off a Burst of 3 rounds at once.  So far, the Techniques pale in comparision to building up Passives but at this stage it's easy to see that things are being worked on.
Scaling enemies.  Enemies appear to go up in levels based on yours, though also based on their location.  The Bandits near your starting HQ stay between Lv.2 and 5 or so, elsewhere they go from Lv.3 to 6 in places.  Obviously balancing encounters and keeping them challenging is important.

Other things I'll comment on are the writing.  The text is clean and easy to follow.  The locations are all unique even amongst incredibly similar areas or businesses.  You won't run into 3 different buildings and find the same generic 'Warehouse'.  While you might not always find a building full of loot, you will know the difference between the Hardware Store, the Thrift Store, and the Pawn Shop.

With full release, there's plenty of side quests and activities to roam around and get involved in as you seek out the fate of your family and how they've fared.  All-in-all, a solid game for the price and a good start for the developer in forging a portfolio of future games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love post-apocalyptic stuff and RPG Maker games, so I've been looking forward to Waste Walkers since I first saw it on Greenlight a couple of months ago.  I'm usually cautious when it comes to early access games, but I'm not worried about this one at all.  The developer posted updates every day (sometimes several in one day) while it was on Greenlight, and actively sought out suggestions from the community.  He's also active in the game's forum.

The game doesn't have a whole lot of content yet, since it just came out and it is early access.  But what's in it so far is a lot of fun, and shows a lot of promise.

Creating a character only takes a few seconds.   You can choose gender, race and name (try naming your character Waste Walker). You can also distribute attribute points and choose a skill or two. The skills range from passive abilities that will help you survive battles, to fighting techniques that will help you win battles.

The ruined city is open-world, so you can roam around checking things out as much as you like.  But the dark fog that constantly surrounds you (you can turn the fog off in the options) and the eerie music creates a real sense of dread. What you do see is blood and destruction, wrecked cars and rubble.  When you turn a corner and bandits run towards you from the shadows, you'll wonder if you'll survive the encounter. You might not...

The sense of urgency from the environment isn't the only survival aspect:  There's also a food/drink system.  If you want to live, you have to scavenge.  (Like the fog effect, the need for food/water can be turned off in the options menu, but  turning it off takes something from the feel of the game.)   You can forage for items and food in containers, abandoned buildings and even in vending machines.  Food not only staves off hunger, it also provides buffs for battles, and some items cure status effects.

Finding as many of these items as possible is important, because fights can be tough.  Even a stray dog can wipe the floor with you if you're not keeping an eye on your HP.  A bandit can flat out murder you. There are random encounters, so you can be attacked almost anywhere,  but there are also enemies roaming around the map with you. Most of the ones I've seen so far have been bandits and wild dogs, but there are creepier things lurking around.  You can save anywhere except for the middle of battle, so that makes dying a little less aggravating.

I'm not going to do a pro/con list or give a rating, since the game is still being developed.  But I will list a few things I'd like to see as soon as possible (some of which are already planned, according to the early access info on the store page):

-More NPCs. I haven't met anyone yet except for people and creatures that want me dead. Some quests and conversations would be nice.  It's possible that I haven't seen anyone yet because I haven't come across a NPC hangout place yet.

-A more reliable way to heal, or a difficulty setting, or both. A hardcore survival experience where you have to keep an eye on dwindling supplies will appeal to a lot of people.  Others won't want it to be this hard.

-Gamepad support.  Using the keyboard works fine, I just prefer using a gamepad with RPG Maker games.

-More classes, skills, and a bigger map.

If you're looking for a fun post-apocalypse survival RPG with retro graphics, here it is, and it's awesome.  Buy it!

reviewText:
Waste Walkers is an indie RPG maker game set in an apocalyptic future filled with ghouls, hounds, bandits and such. You explore a destroyed city searching for your family and attempting to survive. You'll meet people here and there with side quests for you to do, found a couple of them and liked the small dialogues and the characters I met.

There's a ton of loot to use as craft or resell. For the time being I only have 2 crafting recipes and can only craft bandages and such but The crafting system seem elaborated. I liked the fact that the loot is varied and make the world coherent: you find cigarettes, sex magazines, destroyed books, ... I even found a condom! All the objects have an interesting description, sometimes funny, and flesh out the world.
In case you're worried about emptying the world (I managed to do it in some games, that's not good at all, believe me) I saw that the enemies and the containers repoped after an hour or so.

There's also a ton of options that you can modify: fog of war makes your view very small but makes for a better ambiance; Stamina to toggle free run or not; Survival to toggle hunger and thirst, you find a lot of food and realistically the hardest to find is water. You can deactivate everything for a more casual experience or activate everything for a bit of challenge.

The game is set up as a real RPG with attributes and skills and I really liked the skills system: you have 5 points on each level up to pick your skills and can choose active or passive ones, their cost varying from 1 to 5 points. And there's a ton of skills to choose! The battles are really hard at first so I went for passive ones that raises evade and such, and inflict status effects or riposte. That made the battles really easier: I inflict a ton of deadly effects and the enemies basically kill themselves when they manage to hit me, much fun! Interestingly there's an aggro system: you can equip one of your characters with special equipment and buy him special skills so that he becomes the most targeted person in the group. Or the opposite: modify him to be less targeted.

The bad: The game is very rough on the edges. The intro is really raw with barely a few lines, then the character creation isn't detailed; you choose one of 4 propositions, twice. Apparently you first choose your appearance, then an attribute bonus. Luckily I chose 'tough' which gave a nice bonus from what I read in the forum (+25% Max HP, +25% Morale.). The stat screen is filled with a lot of abbreviations, making it a bit confusing. Hint: MSV is the radiation level. There's also several different damages, like puncture. But there's nothing bad there in fact, it's only the profusion of it that makes it hard to understand in the beginning.

So yeah the beginning is very confusing and can leave a bad impression, but if you give it a chance you'll quickly get around it and discover a really enjoyable game. The more I played, the more I got hooked to it and started enjoying it. Went in the loop: have a couple of fights, loot everything and go back to the safe place to trade all that for pills to heal my radiation level, equiping and leveling my character and buying more combat skills. It quickly went into the 'I'll just make one more building', it's hard to stop. And it's the first time that I'm happy to find a rotten fruit in a container to quench my thirst :) Apparently the game is a single guy's work, so I'm rather impressed.

So yeah I do recommend the game. Give it a chance and you're in for some fun. Be your own caravan guy: kill, loot, sell, craft!

What if Fallout had turned out to be a turned based RPG with adorable pixel sprites? Well, I present to you Waste Walkers. From scavenging, getting your face torn off by mutated monsters, and dealing with radiation poisoning, Waste Walker's puts you in the middle of post apocalyptic world and lets you figure out the rest. Starting from nothing, you will have to scratch, gnaw, and fight your way to make something of yourself and be able to survive. This will take time and patience, just about everything wants to kill you and can easily do so. Waste Walkers is a game with many elements and features that take time to explore and fully appreciate, such as crafting, passives, techniques, trading, food conservation, and of course making friends. The only thing this game needs is polish and more of everything. Which the developer already has planned. The only issue is that the game can be brutally difficult. You don't have much in the way of weaponry and little pointing you in the direction of finding them. However long as you save often, death shouldn't be an issue. In all if you want to play a fun, unique mash up of RPG and open world post-apocalyptic game. Check out Waste Walkers.

Okay so before I review I would like to tell everyone or anyone who plans on buying Waste Walkers that this is a Early Access and that it will of course have bugs and glitches..So without further ado! Here is my review of this game called Waste Walkers.

This game is very unique and you start out inside a basement of a house (That might be yours.) and you scavenge for resources that you can use to survive, but before that you can customize your character which is something I find pretty neat!

Your objective is to survive but that's not the only objective..You can choose to help people that need assistance such as getting an item for them.

While i have only came across one glitch it is a really great game so far! The bug or glitch i came across is when you go to the police station and you grab the key to the armory..When I grabbed the key and opened the door it still would not let me through..But that did not ruin the experience for me in anyway..I kinda was happy that it happen because then it would make everything way easier.

Why do I recommend Waste Walkers? Because it is unique and I have yet to see a Survival RPG Maker game on steam..And a game such as this is amazing as it is well done, the developer is new in game designing and needs support. I am willing to lend him my support seeing how he did a great job on this game! Sure I have only had 2 hours in the game..But in those 2 hours, It was a fun experience and I know there might not be much in the game..But i know this game is worth supporting or paying $6.99 for..To be honest i don't think it should be $6.99..But maybe the price will change when it is a full game.

The next thing I like about the game is the hydration and Food meter..Now you have to eat alot in order to heal yourself..Sometimes I eat food so i can heal but sometimes i eat it when I am low on hunger or hyrdration..Regardless I think the food meter and hydration meter is a cool thing because it adds more survival into it..Oh! And did i mention there is a Radiation meter? Well there is! And if you get near vehicles the meter will go up.

Now..I know this is weird and kinda stupid to like..But how the levels of monsters or bandits in Waste Walkers..What i find cool about it is that when you level up, so do the monsters and bandits..Which is pretty impressive because I know that when you are making maps or layers I know it isn't as easy as you think.

Finally here are my thoughts or ideas on what i think should be put in Waste Walkers and if you are reading this developer I hope you continue to soar high and continue to make unique games. You have my support!

Here are ideas or my thoughts on what should be in the game in the future:

Relationship System/Love System - Even when the world ends, People still find love or fight by each other's side.

Pets -You can tame or befriend wild creatures and such.

Storyline - While this may be a game focused on surivival..I would like to see a storyline.

Adoption - In a post-apocalyspe world there are those who no longer have parents..I would love to see a adoption feature so when you saw a child that is outside or whatever by himself/herself then you could choose to adopt him or her.

A bigger world - Exactly as it is titled..This idea would be that you could do some missions or quests and have them completed in order to acquire the item that can lead you to another city, town, area, or world.

House/Fort System - I would love to see this in this type of game because you could litterally be at home but you can get raided and such..Which I think would be pretty cool!

Family system - I think it would be cool to see this espically if you had the house/fort system since you could have certain characters control or maintain certain things.

+Unique system, easy to understand and get into.

Overall score: 8.5/10
Explaination of score: Any fan of the genre at hand will enjoy the game thoroughly, but it won't change any minds or convince any skeptics.

reviewText:
Painful and rewarding. These are the words that describe Waste Walkers.

Combat is mostly meant to be avoided, as these enemies are not mass production mooks.  Each and every enemy has their own perks and abilities, but most importantly, they are fighting to survive, just like you are. Carefully avoiding enemies while you loot containers is a sensible idea, and completeing quests is more effective for gaining exp. Enemies do currently scale with the player and his comrades, but this never feels overly annoying.

Crafting is simple, as are most quests. Simple does not mean easy, as many of these items are in the hands of dangerous individuals or randomly generated. The rewards are subtle, but they will benefit you either in spare cash and exp, or in better services and cheaper supplies. They can even gain you access to powerful and vital supplies. Crafting can help make your life cheaper and easier, once you buy the scematics. Crafting may be limited to what you can make, but they can save you much time, effort and resources if you are determined enough.

It is not to say there are no flaws, but that is mostly due to resource limitations. WW is a large game for an opening title, and is still rather fun.

Overall, Waste Walkers is a survivors fight for his life, and an enjoyable experience for those who likewasteland exploration games.

reviewText:
Waste Walkers, developed by Corrosion Studios, is an open-world survival game created with RPGMaker. Now, I won’t beat around the bush; this is one of the most expansive and intricate games built on this engine, and it’s sure to steal more than a few hours of your time.

The story is fairly standard for a post-apocalyptic setting: The world has been destroyed by nuclear war and mundane life no longer exists. Normal people who lead normal lives must struggle to survive against the war’s aftermath. You’re put in the shoes of a survivor, separated from his/her family. Vague leads and shady individuals are your only guides, and you’ll take whatever you can get to find them.

As stated previously, this is a big game with a lot of stuff crammed inside. The map is littered in side quests, NPCs, monsters, and all sorts of things to explore. Just about every structure has an interior ripe with loot, and believe me, there is a lot of stuff to loot. In fact, a lot of your time will be spent away from the main quest line; mastering the maddness in this shell of a city.

Before going any further, there’s something that should be made clear. This game does not hold your hand. Apart from a short tutorial explaining some basic mechanics, you’re on your own. A lot is left for the player to figure out, and if you’re the type of guy who needs a big, shiny objective marker leading the way, you might want to give Waste Walkers a pass.

You’ve got your typical array of survival mechanics, such as a hydration and hunger bar, topped off with a radiation meter; however, food and water is in large abundance, so keeping healthy is not much of a challenge. What really makes this game difficult is combat, especially in the earlier stages. You start out weak and pathetic. Maintaining ammunition is a challenge at first, and trading punches with every beast crossing your path is NOT a good idea.

Waste Walkers is a game that encourages patience, and with a variety of different survivors to recruit, armor to find and weapons to wield, it won’t be long before you’re ready for a fight…. In fact, maybe you’re a little too ready; after you’ve leveled up and found some decent loot, Waste Walkers challenge goes down the drain. Just about anything will die within a few hits, and the tension slowly dissolves little by little.

Like I said, the game offers little hand holding. I started up Waste Walkers with the wrong frame of mind. I spent a few hours running around aimlessly, getting lost and dying over and over and over. I got so frustrated that I was tempted to quit altogether. To properly enjoy this game, you’ve really gotta know what you’re getting into. Take things slow and try to familiarize yourself with the map, the enemies, the loot, the world as a whole. But trust me; Waste Walkers can get addictive once you know what you’re doing.

I can only recommend this game to those who are well acquainted with the genre, or to those who want to be. But if you’re willing to take the risk, you’ll be in for one hell of a ride.

A surprisingly well excuted use of the RPG Maker engine to produce something more than the usual fare. Mechanics are about as would be predicted for the engine and genre, extended to include welcome survial elements (which I believe can be turned off? Wasn't intrested in doing so myself but do recall seeing that).

The setting might be said to be like Fallout, but unlike Fallout which takes place many decades after an apocolyptic event, Waste Walkers places you in the role of a survivor shortly after whatever happened (it seems to be one of the mysteries of the game) happened. Resources are scarce and heavy enough to make you concerned and wish to create stashes around the city, but not so far as to panic. Combat is very challenging but not impossible, and the survival element is reinforced by some encounters consistantly costing more resources than they reward, making 'fight or flight?' an important question throughout the game.

The two things I felt could have contained more content was the novel and guide found in the Pepper's edition. However those are accurately presented as non essetial content that in no way impacts the game (much like a sound track dlc, they're just additional files of interest to some and not game content) so it's a minor grief of mine.

All around though if you were looking for a lower end post apocolyptic survival game and/or an example of the RPG Maker engine being pushed to produce something different than the stereotypical content people have come to expect, Waste Walkers is worth a shot. Kinda looking forward to the author's next project as well.

Been trying to post a review for the new DLC through the usual method, on the DLC page, but Steam doesn't seem to want to let me so... figure I'll try adding it to the end of this. So this is for the Deliverance DLC

Key for DLC provided by the developer for reviewing purposes, which was really nice of him. Thanks to Corrosion!

Deliverance plays as a separate game from standard Waste Walkers using the same engine. When you load Waste Walkers a Steam dialog pops up to ask you which of the two games you wish to play. I'm a bit torn as to if Deliverance would have been better posted as a separate game (perhaps billed as a sequel), rather than as a DLC to Waste Walkers, but I can definitely say that your experience in the base Waste Walkers game is not effected by having Deliverance or not.

Rather than creating your own custom character as in Waste Walkers you start as the character Screw, with a few stat points and skills already taken as well as his own backstory. The skill system is the same as Waste Walkers though, so you'll quickly be setting up your own style of character anyway within a couple of levels.

Combat is much more difficult than in Waste Walkers in a good way, early on guns beyond the pipe weapons that fire improvised ammo made with nails are nearly impossible to find even in the shops prior to completing a certain story mission.

After a few plays I was finding tabs (the currency of the Waste Walkers world, similar to caps from Fallout) were easy to come by in standard Waste Walkers, while in Deliverance I was doing more to manage them so that I could afford what limited armor and weapons was available for purchase. There's also a great deal more crafting going on in Deliverance, with almost all of the vendors offering a few schematics for sale to make items of varying usefulness. First aid kids, survival kits and med packs were probably the items I found the most useful to craft, allowing me to carry a few more effective items rather than a larger number of minor supplies.

Deliverance has quite a bit more writing and character than Waste Walkers, and while it could still use some polish (odd moments such as a character walking wounded into a room she was expected to be found in, rather than being found wounded in the room could have been staged to make a touch more sense) it shows a major step up from the previous entry. NPCs are a bit more fleshed out and human in their interactions, and events flow together in a cohesive manner. There's quite a few more quests as well, though perhaps a few of those from NPCs at the base area could have been spread out by delaying them until later in the story. Felt as though a glut of them were presented at the outset, then as I progressed through the main story there weren't as many minor side quests to pursue.

So overall a good amount of fun, and if I were to pick one thing I'd like to have seen differently it'd be having Deliverance as a separate game from Waste Walkers. The difference in overall quality and enjoyment is significant enough that it almost feels awkward having it as a DLC.

Yes. It's finally here - Waste Walker. And let me tell you: it is 101% worth your money(10€), trust me :)

In a nutshell, Waste Walkers is a post-apocalyptic RPG - based on the RPG-Maker - with a lot of refinment to it.

GameplayGameplay of Waste Walker is fun:

The games main focus is not combat - and especially fighting for yourself - but staying alive.
You walk around, find more party members, manage consumption, complete quest and propgress through the story.
The game is difficult, I like it. I will admit that I've died many times in the game, that's ok. When I died, in the game, I took it as a very important lesson. When I returned to that area that I previously died in, I knew how to tackle my past mistake.
Combat of Waste Walkers is turned-based, half random-encounters half in-field enemies.

graphics
Graphics in Waste Walkers is 16-bit sprite-based with a post-apocalyptic twist to it.
I like  the games evirement, atmosphere and feel to it. But, at times, the immersion breaks when I see suits of armour, swords and other medievel-fantasy things that doesn't belong.
Other than that, I don't know what to say about the graphics.

StoryYou may have noticed that I've been talking about Waste Walkers gameplay, refinment and envirement and not much about the story. well... that is because, I haven't gotten that far in to the story. Reason why I haven't progressed that far in the game is because it's easy to get lost in the game - there is a map but it's not really that helpful.

Story of Waste Walkers starts of with a prologue-text. In a nutshell, the text recaps how war has destroyed earth as we know it and now it's filled with mutated monsters, gangs, thugs and many other terrible things. But! ''There is HOPE''.

ConclusionWaste Walker is one of those RPGMaker games that will always stand out in my mind due to it being a post-apocalyptic-RPG, and not just another medieval-RPG like most RPG-maker games are.

Pros and Cons:

Pro:
-not that many many bugs.
-Difficult.
-a lot of content.
-you are not forced to use a gamepad.
-...And last, but not least, one of my favourite features on Waste Walkers is: a mouse cursor.  My gamepad has been acting very strange lately. So I was very glad that Waste Walkers didn't force me to use a Gamepad like almost every RPGmaker game out there.

Keep up the good work, Corrosion :)

With the game still currently in beta I can understand there are elements still needing to be refined and with the short playtime I have on record thus far which at the time of the review is only about four hours at most. I find a appealing factor in Waste Walkers, one of which is brought upon the enjoyments I find out of other games such as Fallout which no doubt is the game's premise centered around. The system has a while to go until it is fully layered to the point where replayability can be found. Some of the quests (Such as one involving a couple in the department store) could do with more plot development other than a guilt tripped woman going about her life in a monotonous pattern. You could argue that these strangers bare no important role in the big picture and that I would agree upon; however with quests that are straight forward. However, I have given the game a shot and I believe in my own opinion it has aspects of which are desired. Aspects of which to grow and expand, lessons to step forward with and to become its own community of wastelanders. I truly believe that for a start up beta, what is offered currently is enough to drive itself further and further. IF Corrosive Studios is capable of pushing their work of art in the proper direction and building a game not just merely a clone of what Fallout is, but a unique blend of what a survival rpg is. For this genre is riddled with video games that just don't chalk up to what they desire to be and with the first steps Waste Walkers has taken and the aspects of its survival, the managment of resources, the exploration of a expanding world and the ability to not only live a story through a character but to write your own story in it of itself is appealing to be in the helm of. Right off the bat Waste Walkers captured my attention with a rather different approach to an RPG game than I've been used to lately. Whereas most stories start off by telling you that you have to go here or there to progress — WW did not. Waste walkers spins it's tale through the derelict buildings throughout the Ashen City, and playing with the Fog of War on gives off an eerie Silent Hill vibe.

The first few hours of the game are a breath of fresh air in comparison to what you'll encounter in the usual gamut of RPGs. You have a journal, a map, and some quest text. That's all you'll get for the rest of the game, and it's also part of the charm of figuring out what you have to do next. Careful planning and ammo conservation are key in the early game, and you run the risk of dying very often early on if you're not paying attention to your surroundings.

Environment and music are something the game pulls off well. Each area has a careful attention to detail, and the 30+ buildings that I've explored all have a unique touch to them. From the Cinema to the Police Station — all of them have a special look and feel different from the other areas. Where the story itself is scarce the environment picks up the pace with minimalist storytelling done through the range of NPCs and monsters that roam the Ashen City.

Combat is rather barebones once you really get down into the nit and gritty, but I have to say that it didn't really detract from the game in any way. Managing supplies/needs, health, and inventory doesn't feel like a chore. After a while you'll be able to tell what's worth taking, and what's worth leaving behind amidst your limited inventory space. The base mechanics of the game just work. They don't need the extra flair of 40 skills and abilities that all do the same thing. Maybe a little more push towards using debuffs, or forcing weapon proficiency skills on the player would give choosing a weapon type a weightier decision, but it's a minor gripe if anything.

The only real complaint I would have is that late-game scaling gets a little weird, and it's entirely possible to trivialize the combat if you've managed your resources properly. Better enemy scaling would provide a more clean transition into the late game, but it hasn't hindered my ability to enjoy the game.

8 hours in at the time of reviewing, and I'm still having a lot of fun with it. As of late I've been drawn to RPGMaker games due to growing tired of games giving me a story in hour long exposition with a cutscene. Waste Walkers is a gem for me, and I can see myself enjoying it for quite a bit longer. Give it a try. The developer certainly seems to have put a lot of love into the game and it shows.

Best of wishes to Corrosion and his future endeavors. I look forward to seeing what you do next.

So what exactly is Waste Walkers?

Waste Walkers is a Survival Game created by RPGMaker, and if you have ever played a JRPG, you will know what I am speaking about.

Now I won't be rating the graphics or sound since these are not the backbone of this particular game (as in all JRPG's). Gameplay, and Replayability is what drives this particular title, and the developer has added a few things which make this title different.

The world where you wake up in is post apocalyptic dangerous wasteland where you will meet up with Ghouls, Raiders, and all kinds of nasties as you try to figure out where you have to go if you follow the story line.

As in all other JRPG's combat is turn based which is what I am use too, and enjoy. Here is a small list of things that make this title stand out.

#1: Starting Out: (You start by creating your character, and there are a few types to choose from, and make sure you choose, and apply your stats wisely. It can make all the difference in this world believe me.)

#2: Loot type & Loot location are Randomized: (Whenever you start a new game expect the loot to change it's location, and no two locations will hold the same type of loot either. This adds a whole lot of replayability.)

#3: Food/Water/Rads: (You now have to worry about Food, Water, and Radiation on top of everything else, so stock up well, and I suggest that you store allot of your life saving loot throughout the map as safe zones. I have learned the hard way here.)

#4: Crafting: (You will have plenty of opportunity to collect blueprints/crafting abilities which has really added another great feature too this game, once more a beautifully done bit for replayability.)

#5: Survival: (There is more than one way to play this game. You can concentrate on your skills, and weaponry, and take the world on, or stay quite, sneak about, or do both depending on how you skill up, and arm your character. There are a few ways to play this game, and again it's all about survival in this world.)

... The list is pretty large actually.

I have played several JRPG's in the past, and I can honestly tell you that this game has many great things going for it, and add in the replayability value, you will be playing this game a few times just to see how other characters handle being on the outside.

My Overall Score: 8.5 out of 10

-=FINAL=-

Do I recommend the game?

Yes I do without a shadow of a doubt. Believe me, if you are a JRPG/RPGMaker fan like myself, get it, you won't regret it one little bit.

reviewText:
Right off the bat Waste Walkers captured my attention with a rather different approach to an RPG game than I've been used to lately. Whereas most stories start off by telling you that you have to go here or there to progress — WW did not. Waste walkers spins it's tale through the derelict buildings throughout the Ashen City, and playing with the Fog of War on gives off an eerie Silent Hill vibe.

The first few hours of the game are a breath of fresh air in comparison to what you'll encounter in the usual gamut of RPGs. You have a journal, a map, and some quest text. That's all you'll get for the rest of the game, and it's also part of the charm of figuring out what you have to do next. Careful planning and ammo conservation are key in the early game, and you run the risk of dying very often early on if you're not paying attention to your surroundings.

Environment and music are something the game pulls off well. Each area has a careful attention to detail, and the 30+ buildings that I've explored all have a unique touch to them. From the Cinema to the Police Station — all of them have a special look and feel different from the other areas. Where the story itself is scarce the environment picks up the pace with minimalist storytelling done through the range of NPCs and monsters that roam the Ashen City.

Combat is rather barebones once you really get down into the nit and gritty, but I have to say that it didn't really detract from the game in any way. Managing supplies/needs, health, and inventory doesn't feel like a chore. After a while you'll be able to tell what's worth taking, and what's worth leaving behind amidst your limited inventory space. The base mechanics of the game just work. They don't need the extra flair of 40 skills and abilities that all do the same thing. Maybe a little more push towards using debuffs, or forcing weapon proficiency skills on the player would give choosing a weapon type a weightier decision, but it's a minor gripe if anything.

The only real complaint I would have is that late-game scaling gets a little weird, and it's entirely possible to trivialize the combat if you've managed your resources properly. Better enemy scaling would provide a more clean transition into the late game, but it hasn't hindered my ability to enjoy the game.

8 hours in at the time of reviewing, and I'm still having a lot of fun with it. As of late I've been drawn to RPGMaker games due to growing tired of games giving me a story in hour long exposition with a cutscene. Waste Walkers is a gem for me, and I can see myself enjoying it for quite a bit longer. Give it a try. The developer certainly seems to have put a lot of love into the game and it shows.

Best of wishes to Corrosion and his future endeavors. I look forward to seeing what you do next.

I came to this game and immediately found it interesting.  Very similar to RPGs of the past, this game relies on map navigation and battles take you to a separate screen where you fight in turn-based combat style.  After a number of hours playing, though, I found the game frustrating and extremely confusing.  Fortunately, I was able to get a hold of the developer who seemed to genuinely care about my input into the game.  The game itself has great potential and, while it is an unfinished product, is continually being updated.  If you want to decide whether to get this game, here are some of the pro's and cons:
Pro's--the exploration is fun and there is a lot of exploring to do in the game.  Fog-of-war makes for intense travel, though this option is toggleable.  The game is constantly being updated and the owner seems to be making an extra effort to change the game and listen to his customer's input, while at the same time continuing on the theme and direction of his game that he's had.  There is a crafting system in the game and many interesting locations to discover, as well as some basic quests you can find to do for good rewards.  The music is nice and creepy, which is aesthetically pleasing for those who like the 'zombie' feel to a game (though there are no zombies in this one!--too bad :().  There are a host of weapons, armor, and items to find and use to give you an advantage over the many enemies out there that will most likely tear you a new hole if you aren't careful (especially at the beginning).
Con's--while the game has great potential and is improving everyday, it still has it's flaws--and some of them major.  Because it is an RPG-based game, anyone who seeks these elements may be disappointed with the level progression for stat-based characters.  I've played a dex-based character and an endurance-based character and I can honestly say--dex seems nearly meaningless (and even this he has changed a bit recently, so I can't say if this is still ongoing).  If you go all-out endurance and gain access to respectable armor, fighting enemies will be cakewalk, even ones 1-2 levels above you.  If you choose any other statistic to focus on, you'll get ♥♥♥♥♥.  And not just a little bit.  Like--2-3 round ♥♥♥♥ before you die.  The stats I would say are currently extremely unbalanced.  The other major issues I have is, the game completely lacks a glossary of terms and a manual to give even the noob basic pertinent information to survive in his/her adventure.  While they have a 10 page intro, that information should be readily accessible at any given time (because most noobies forget stuff like this).  But even so, the 10 page tutorial doesn't cover many of the frequent abbreviations and/or terms you might be wondering (what the hell does this do?)  Also, there is no functional map.  They have schematics for maps, but none of them work.  Because of how this game is built--its not like a square by square dungeon with easy navigational mapping--I think it's absolutely essential to have a map for this game.  There should be, if nothing else, an offline map we can access--but to my knowledge there isn't even this.  The last thing I found very irritating is the MP bar (and don't confuse this with magic points, as I did and ended up dying a number of times till I realized it wasn't magic!).  In every RPG I have ever played, MP refers to magic points, it is just below the HP bar, and it is the color blue.  Well, their 'moral' bar fits all of these bills, as well as having the abbreviation MP on the status screens...but it's not magic points >_<.  I think the developer will change this, but for any noobie playing this, I can guarantee you would have confused this for magic points unless you read my review.  In addition, pretty much most places you go in to the game and loot--it's all the same stuff.  You're looting meds, food, and drink.  There is the occasional place that has housed some guns (which I've found much later on), but these places are so few and far between it makes little difference.
With this said, the game is improving and has great potential.  The owner went out of his way (even spending hours with me offering tips--though not all were good ones--and I was delighted to see that he cared and took the ones he felt would improve his game and has/will implement them.
